topics.Objective: To analyze what makes a business succeed or fail.
topics.Explanation:
• Not all businesses thrive—some do better than others. 
 • Entrepreneurs must study what works and why. 
 • Learning from others helps plan smarter businesses.
topics.Activity 1:
Business Clue Hunt
Materials Needed: Internet access or printed business case examples.
Steps to Follow:
• Read a short business story.
• Identify what helped it succeed or caused it to fail.
• List key lessons learned.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identifying patterns in entrepreneurship.
What is Gained:
• Critical thinking
• Strategic awareness
topics.Activity 2:
Business Makeover
Materials Needed: Drawing tools or digital slide tool.
Steps to Follow:
• Take a business that didn’t succeed.
• Redesign its plan or branding.
• Present the makeover idea.
What Should Be Achieved:
Reinvention thinking.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Problem-solving
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To explore saving, spending, and investing as an entrepreneur.
topics.Explanation:
• Entrepreneurs need strong financial habits. 
 • Kids can explore budgeting and tracking money. 
 • Saving and investing grow future ideas.

Budget Tracker

Steps to Follow:
• Track weekly spending with allowance or play money.
• Categorize into needs, wants, and savings.
• Reflect on choices.
What Should Be Achieved:
Awareness of money flow.
What is Gained:
• Budgeting
• Value analysis
topics.Activity 2:
Invest-a-Story
Materials Needed: Story prompts, paper.
Steps to Follow:
• Read a short fictional business story.
• Decide how much to invest and why.
• Share choices with others.
What Should Be Achieved:
Simulated investing decisions.
What is Gained:
• Risk evaluation
• Strategic judgment

topics.Explanation:
• Some businesses solve social or environmental problems. 
 • These are called social enterprises. 
 • Kids can start thinking about their own helpful ideas.
topics.Activity 1:
Helping Hands Board
Materials Needed: Chart paper, sticky notes.
Steps to Follow:
• Write down community problems on sticky notes.
• Group them into themes.
• Discuss possible solutions.
What Should Be Achieved:
Community awareness.
What is Gained:
• Empathy
• Brainstorming skills
topics.Activity 2:
Eco-Friendly Pitch
Materials Needed: Recyclables, craft tools.
Steps to Follow:
• Create a product that helps the planet.
• Present it with a simple explanation.
• Reflect on why it helps.
What Should Be Achieved:
Designing for good.
What is Gained:
• Innovation
• Environmental thinking

• Design thinking involves empathizing, defining, ideating, prototyping, and testing. 
 • It's used to solve real problems creatively. 
 • Kids can try the full cycle through fun challenges.

Empathy Explorer

Steps to Follow:
• Interview someone about a challenge they face.
• Write down what they feel, need, and want.
• Use this to define a design problem.
What Should Be Achieved:
Step one of design thinking.
What is Gained:
• Listening
• Problem framing
topics.Activity 2:
Prototype Challenge
Materials Needed: Building blocks, paper, tape.
Steps to Follow:
• Build a solution to the defined problem.
• Test it with a friend or adult.
• Improve based on feedback.
What Should Be Achieved:
Design thinking in action.
What is Gained:
• Iterative learning
• Creative confidence
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Explanation:
• Business has changed over time—from barter to online stores. 
 • Knowing history helps plan the future. 
 • Kids can imagine what businesses might look like tomorrow.
topics.Activity 1:
Business Timeline
Materials Needed: Timeline template, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Place key types of businesses on a timeline.
• Add images or symbols.
• Discuss how tools and markets evolved.
What Should Be Achieved:
Seeing business as an evolving journey.
What is Gained:
• Historical insight
• Big-picture thinking
topics.Activity 2:
Future Storefront
Materials Needed: Drawing paper, crayons or digital art.
Steps to Follow:
• Imagine a business in the year 2050.
• Draw its logo, tools, and customers.
• Explain how it works.
What Should Be Achieved:
Visualizing future trends.
What is Gained:
• Futuristic imagination
• Visionary thinking
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Explanation:
• Simulating a start-up teaches planning and execution. 
 • They learn how ideas turn into real ventures. 
 • It encourages long-term thinking.

Steps to Follow:
• Choose a fun business idea.
• Plan steps like name, logo, team, and what’s sold.
• Stick notes for each phase.
What Should Be Achieved:
Visualize the journey of a start-up.
What is Gained:
• Strategic planning
• Problem-solving
topics.Activity 2:
Sim Shop
Materials Needed: Toy money, printables for store items.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up a mini pretend shop.
• Take roles of buyer, seller, investor.
What Should Be Achieved:
Simulate early-stage business roles.
What is Gained:
• Role understanding
• Business interaction

• An MVP is the simplest version of a product. 
 • It’s a test to see if an idea works. 
 • Helps avoid waste and improve early.

Just Enough

Steps to Follow:
• Think of a business idea.
• Draw only the most important feature.
• Ask a friend if they’d use it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identify MVP essentials.
What is Gained:
• Prioritization
• Feedback loop
topics.Activity 2:
Test Time
Materials Needed: Short survey or feedback form.
Steps to Follow:
• Share MVP idea with family.
• Collect responses on likes and improvements.
What Should Be Achieved:
Early market testing.
What is Gained:
• Iterative thinking
• User perspective
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To teach how failure can lead to better ideas.
topics.Explanation:
• Entrepreneurs often fail before succeeding. 
 • Learning from mistakes helps growth. 
 • Failure builds resilience.
topics.Activity 1:
Famous Fails
Materials Needed: Cards with failed products or ideas.
Steps to Follow:
• Read about failures (e.g. inventions, ideas).
• Guess why they failed and what improved later.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand failure as part of learning.
What is Gained:
• Growth mindset
• Risk tolerance
topics.Activity 2:
My Oops Moment
Materials Needed: Journal or notebook.
Steps to Follow:
• Write about a small personal failure.
• Note what you learned and how you'd do it differently.
What Should Be Achieved:
Reflect on learning from setbacks.
What is Gained:
• Self-awareness
• Adaptability
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To practice creating a powerful business pitch.
topics.Explanation:
• A pitch explains your idea in a short, clear way. 
 • It shows value, uniqueness, and impact. 
 • Builds public speaking and clarity.
topics.Activity 1:
60-Second Pitch
Materials Needed: Timer, idea notes.
Steps to Follow:
• Pick a product idea.
• Create a 1-minute pitch to explain it.
• Time yourself and repeat to improve.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn concise pitching.
What is Gained:
• Public speaking
• Communication clarity
topics.Activity 2:
Pitch Parade
Materials Needed: Small audience of friends/family.
Steps to Follow:
• Present your pitch to the group.
• Take one question each.
What Should Be Achieved:
Build audience confidence.
What is Gained:
• Confidence
• Thinking on your feet
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To learn how trends influence business.
topics.Explanation:
• Entrepreneurs look for trends to spot new ideas. 
 • Trends come from social changes, tech, or style. 
 • Timing is key to success.
topics.Activity 1:
Future Lens
Materials Needed: Magazines, online articles.
Steps to Follow:
• Read or browse for what's becoming popular.
• Circle interesting new products or behaviors.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identify emerging trends.
What is Gained:
• Market awareness
• Observation
topics.Activity 2:
Trend to Idea
Materials Needed: Drawing paper, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Pick one trend spotted.
• Sketch a business based on that trend.
What Should Be Achieved:
Turn trend into opportunity.
What is Gained:
• Creative forecasting
• Design thinking
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To understand how branding shapes identity.
topics.Explanation:
• Branding includes logo, colors, and message. 
 • A strong brand stands out and tells a story. 
 • It builds trust and recognition.
topics.Activity 1:
Logo Launch
Materials Needed: Paper, pencils, colored pens.
Steps to Follow:
• Think of a fun business idea.
• Design a logo and choose 2 brand colors.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand brand visuals.
What is Gained:
• Visual thinking
• Identity creation
topics.Activity 2:
Slogan Spark
Materials Needed: Word cards, paper.
Steps to Follow:
• Create a catchy one-line slogan for your business.
• Make sure it matches the logo idea.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect idea to message.
What is Gained:
• Wordplay
• Communication clarity
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To explore businesses that solve real-world problems.
topics.Explanation:
• Social entrepreneurs mix profit with purpose. 
 • They solve problems like hunger, pollution, or access. 
 • Makes business meaningful.
topics.Activity 1:
Problem Spotter
Materials Needed: News clippings or issue list.
Steps to Follow:
• Look at common problems around you.
• Pick one and think of a solution.
What Should Be Achieved:
See opportunities in challenges.
What is Gained:
• Empathy
• Social awareness
topics.Activity 2:
Pitch for Good
Materials Needed: Note cards, timer.
Steps to Follow:
• Pitch your idea as if to help a community.
• Emphasize impact and need.
What Should Be Achieved:
Link profit to purpose.
What is Gained:
• Ethical thinking
• Idea presentation
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To understand how entrepreneurship changed over time.
topics.Explanation:
• Businesses evolve with tech and culture. 
 • Past businesses inspire new ideas. 
 • Encourages timeline thinking.
topics.Activity 1:
Business Then & Now
Materials Needed: Printouts or sketches of old businesses.
Steps to Follow:
• Compare how a business worked 50 years ago vs. now.
• Discuss what changed and what stayed.
What Should Be Achieved:
Recognize evolution of business.
What is Gained:
• Historical view
• Comparative thinking
topics.Activity 2:
Future Biz Sketch
Materials Needed: Drawing sheet, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Imagine the same business 50 years in the future.
• Draw or explain how it might change.
What Should Be Achieved:
Forecast business transformation.
What is Gained:
• Imagination
• Futuristic thinking
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To introduce the connection between entrepreneurship and finance.
topics.Explanation:
• Entrepreneurs must manage earnings and costs. 
 • Smart money moves build strong businesses. 
 • Finance decisions shape future growth.
topics.Activity 1:
Budget Challenge
Materials Needed: Fake currency, list of costs.
Steps to Follow:
• Plan how to spend ₹100 on business needs.
• Choose between product, marketing, savings.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn money decision-making.
What is Gained:
• Budget skills
• Prioritization
topics.Activity 2:
Profit Puzzle
Materials Needed: Simple math worksheet.
Steps to Follow:
• Calculate revenue and cost from a toy business.
• Subtract to find profit.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand profit formula.
What is Gained:
• Math fluency
• Business logic
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development

topics.Objective: To explore what happens when a business ends or is sold.
topics.Explanation:
• Entrepreneurs may sell or close a business. 
 • Exit strategies help prepare for transitions. 
 • Teaches closure and reinvention.
topics.Activity 1:
Sale Scenario
Materials Needed: Role-play slips, fake contracts.
Steps to Follow:
• Role-play selling a business to a buyer.
• Decide what the new owner can change.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand business transfer.
What is Gained:
• Negotiation skills
• Letting go
topics.Activity 2:
What’s Next?
Materials Needed: Writing journal.
Steps to Follow:
• Write what you'd do after selling your business.
• Would you start again? Retire?
What Should Be Achieved:
Imagine post-business paths.
What is Gained:
• Future planning
• Entrepreneurial reflection
topics.path_description: Entrepreneurial mindset and business skills development
